of performing calculations on a counting board and with help of roman numerals, the theory of
ratios (as an introduction to musica), biblical numerology and the computus rules. Many Christian
thinkers tended to agree upon the date of June 12, 5012 BC at noon, as the time for Creation. In a
time that the Bible was considered the most important text, one can imagine that these kind of
calculations were of the utmost importance. Musica consisted of the theory of chords in connection
to ratios of string length, and the ways to indicate notes. The art of geometria was mostly
restricted to knowledge of the names of various geometrical objects. Triangles, cones, spheres
and the regular solids were interesting for their connection to the world order. The equilateral
triangle, for example, was viewed in connection to the Holy Trinity. Mostly the objects themselves
were considered fascinating: proofs were not considered important, although use of the
Pythagorean theorem was known. Finally, astronomia consisted of knowledge about movement
of the stars and planets on the basis of the Ptolemaic system. The connection with astrology was
not always popular, since it seemed to deny the possibility of a free choice of will. At courts,
however, trust in or need for predictions was in cases considered more important than religious
piety. So in practice, the knowledge of astrology was still valued and this implied interest in geometria
as well.

Euclid seemed to be forgotten. The few manuscripts kept in the libraries of monasteries were
hardly consulted until the 10th century. Boethius, on the contrary, was kept alive. The interest of
Christian thinkers for knowledge of the quadrivium was mostly for its mystical aspects and for
the rules it had to offer. The fact that it was framed in four subjects that were fundamental and
essential in the education of every free man, and that were not considered to be trivial (contrary
to the subjects within the trivium), does illustrate the fact that knowledge of geometria and
arithmetica was valued, albeit for completely different reasons than we might recognise. Number
and geometrical objects, through the ideas in musica and astronomia offered the possibility to
make the human mind rise to reach spiritual truths that were considered valuable. As such, it
was only natural that this knowledge would play a role in churches, monasteries and objects of
art, visible and audible in the positioning of buildings, musical masses and christian iconography.
In a way, this implied a Christian version of the Platonic ideas about geometria, God had created
the world either with help of knowledge of geometria, or had hidden its purities in His Creation.
That made the field of knowledge worthy of study, if only because one wanted to be able to
recognise these elements in Creation.
Rise of the universitas
The life of Gerbert of Aurillac (946-1003) may be considered important to the rise of mathematical
thinking in Europe. In three ways, his life illustrates that a new kind of purpose for the fields of
geometria and arithmetica was growing in importance. One could say, Gerbert illustrates how
mathematics was cashing in on the possibilities it held for Christian philosophy. First of all, Gerbert
studied. He traveled extensively to find and read manuscripts and also studied texts from
non- and pre-Christian origin. His interest for Euclidean manuscripts gave impetus to his work De
Geometria: a compilation of what he understood from The Elements, that became widespread
through his extensive network of correspondence. It is easy to be dismissive of his grasp of Euclids
work, of which indeed, his knowledge would remain superficial, the correspondence giving
evidence to shear endless confusion about the question what Euclid could have meant with the
exterior angle in a triangle. But the level of understanding is not as important as the fact that he
did make these fields relevant, and open to study. To summarize: Gerbert set a new ideal of studying.
Trying to understand something new, either by studying different sources or by thinking
for oneself, and testing knowledge by discussing it with others — in correspondence or life —
was normalised.
Second, not only did he set a new standard to studying, he also managed to popularise it because
he was an influential Christian thinker. Perhaps it was exactly his newly acquired knowledge
that made him stand out at the court of emperor Otto II, perhaps he was already well connected
and the emperor stimulated him in his studies. Whatever was the case, Gerbert was an important
man at the imperial court. In those days it was only too easy to be dismissive of someone who
had studied geometria and arithmetica, certainly when his knowledge came from dubious and
Mathematical worlds 38
even heretic sources. A pact with the devil was easily suggested, and that made it impossible to
rise in the ranks of the court or the church. Political and papal opponents of Gerbert indeed did
try to blacken him, but the fact that they didn’t succeed in blocking his rising star, first as the tutor
of the later Otto III at the imperial court, and his eventual election to be the pope under the
name of Sylvester II, illustrates that indeed his way of studying became a new example. If only
accessible to the privileged, study would become a prerequisite for many positions — an idea
that would soon be copied by those who wanted to mimic the (papal) aristocracy.
Third, and this might have been most significant, Gerbert took non Christian knowledge serious.
Of course he was a very pious man, but by studying Arab and Greek manuscripts and taking
them at face value, and by the influential man he was (or became) by his position, he greatly enhanced
the possibilities of study. Most notably, Gerbert visited the Muselmen libraries of the Iberian
peninsula. That is where he learned about Roman surveying techniques, use of the abacus
and Arab numerals. With his impact on the political and cultural ways of his time, this made
knowledge of the ancient arts of geometria and arithmetica open to a more fundamental role in
European society.
Knowledge, in the shape of books and scrolls, was in the possession of monasteries. Libraries in
such enormous monastery cities such as Cluny, set an example to the orders. Most notably in the
wealthy cities, where the monasteries with help of local wealth would create enormous cathedrals
that helped to spread the splendour, grandeur and superiority of Christianity and its God
far beyond the city limits, knowledge was also considered as wealth. Either the court or local

was considered part of that. The presence of manuscripts, attracting scholars who wanted to
study these, in combination with eager students who wanted a part of that knowledge, made
that exactly at these kind of places, the first cathedral schools were founded: Bologna (1088), the
Sorbonne (1150) and Oxford (1164) all started a universitas, as it was called. A universitas was a
group of scholars, mostly monks, that debated among each other and who took pupils to educate
on any subject they wanted to be taught in. The universitas was greatly valued by city or court
officials, who could benefit from the knowledge that dwelled in these places, and so it became
customary that these places were funded and granted certain privileges. For example, students
and professors at the universitas were exempted from paying taxes on the consumption of alcohol,
in many places members of the universitas were allowed to carry weapons, and were subject
to their own courts and internal laws. Thereby, the universitas developed into an own cultural
center, a subculture with its own rules and habits, within society. And in that new subculture, the
use and purpose of knowledge of geometria and arithmetica could develop in a direction different
from that outside its walls. And so it did.
